choices.D: Create regular tables with default Time Travel and Fail-safe settings.
choices.C: Create regular tables with extended Time Travel and Fail-safe settings.
choices.A: Create transient tables and periodically copy them to permanent tables.
choices.B: Create temporary tables and periodically copy them to permanent tables.

questions.question_text: How can a user MINIMIZE Continuous Data Protection costs when using large, high-churn, dimension tables?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - transient table are basically the same as regular table but do not utilize fail safe hence reducing the storage cost involved with them https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/tables-temp-transient#transient-tables

For large, high-churn dimension tables that incur overly-excessive CDP costs, the solution is to create these tables as transient with zero Time Travel retention (i.e. DATA_RETENTION_TIME_IN_DAYS=0) and then copy these tables on a periodic basis into a permanent table.

Selected Answer: C
C - SnowSQL is a command line tool and BD makes no sense

Selected Answer: C
It's the only answer

choices.E: Column-level security allows the application of a masking policy to a column within a table or view.
choices.B: Column-level security supports encryption of the entire database.
choices.A: Implementation of column-level security will optimize query performance.
choices.C: Column-level security ensures that only the table owner can access the data.
choices.D: Column-level security limits access to specific columns within a table based on user privileges.

questions.question_text: In Snowflake's data security framework, how does column-level security contribute to the protection of sensitive information? (Choose two.)

choices.C: It automatically allocates additional resources to improve query execution.
choices.B: It compresses the data within micro-partitions for faster querying.
choices.A: It prunes unnecessary micro-partitions based on clustering metadata.
choices.D: It organizes clustering information to speed-up data retrieval from storage.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Snowflake uses clustering metadata to identify and eliminate irrelevant micro-partitions during query execution, which significantly improves query performance by reducing the amount of data scanned.

Selected Answer: A
I would say A

Selected Answer: B
I think answer is B.
Benefits of Defining Clustering Keys (for Very Large Tables):
Better column compression than in tables with no clustering. This is especially true when other columns are strongly correlated with the columns that comprise the clustering key.
